events.name: Women Techmakers: Design Thinking Workshop: The Female Perspective in Technology
events.description:
Google Women Techmakers Event: Design Thinking Workshop: The Female Perspective in Technology
To celebrate International Womens Day GDG Chicago will host a Women Techmakers design sprint workshop at 1871 on March 24 from 6-8:30pm.

Join Us! 
Women are 50% of the population but do their opinions and voices influence and reflect 50% of the technology and applications that surround us? Join us for a special design sprint and workshop to celebrate International Womens Day!

• Learn design thinking methods you can use for your projects or entrepreneurial ideas

• Develop a technical understanding of current technology trends including mobile apps, wearables, internet of things, virtual reality, and web applications

• Explore current technology trends from female perspectives

• Learn the basics of transforming and iterating an idea into a startup or digital product through design thinking

Event Details:
Join us for lightning talks on tech trends, play with some new tech, design thinking workshop, some great food, drinks and raffle prizes. 

What is Design Thinking?
Design thinking is a proven and repeatable problem solving UX development method that anyone can employ to generate innovative ideas and solutions to problems.

What Tech Will I Learn About?
Wearables
Internet of Things
Mobile Technologies
Virtual Reality
Web Technologies

What is Women Techmakers?
A global team of Googlers who are passionate about empowering women in technology through increased visibility, community, and resources.
https://www.womentechmakers.com/

events.name: You Can't Do That on Television

venue.name: Groupon - Third Floor, The Big Wet Training Room

events.description:
You Can't Do That on Television by Dusty Burwell

Google recently changed the landscape of home media with a $35 device the size of a pack of gum. Perhaps more compelling is that this device has made it easier than ever to develop applications for the television. This talk will translate your existing, well honed web development skills into the tools necessary to reach the largest screen in your living room. Green slime will not be included.

About Dusty Burwell

Dusty has been developing software professionally for 10 years. He now specializes in Javascript and Node.js working for Groupon in Chicago, but spent his past lives building software in both .Net and Java technologies. Dusty has shown a commitment to the community by founding and contributing to a diverse set of user groups, conferences, and educational initiatives.

GDG Chicago Events

Food is always provided!

Food and Venue for this event is sponsored by:

While at Groupon please follow their Code of Conduct

Make sure to let us know if you need building access! Answer the "RSVP Question" with your full name.

events.name: Intro To Polymer: Google's Web Components
events.description:
Intro To Polymer: Google's Web Components presented by Dan Baran

Web Components usher in a new era of web development based on encapsulated and interoperable custom elements that extend HTML itself. Built atop these new standards, Polymer makes it easier and faster to create anything from a button to a complete application across desktop, mobile, and beyond.

Come learn more about Polymer and all it has to offer at GDG Chicago!

Agenda:

6:00 - 6:30 - Networking and Food
6:30 - 6:45 - Introduction and Announcements
6:45 - 7:45 - Intro to Polymer Presented by Dan Baran
7:45 - 8:15 - Networking

events.name: Google I/O Extended Event
events.description:
Join us for the biggest annual Google party! Google I/O Extended Chicago

Please join Google Developer Group Chicago and Motorola Mobility in learning about the year ahead in tech.  Together we'll explore the latest in tech, mobile & beyond.  We will be streaming the Google I/O keynote live, serving lunch, and providing panel discussions and tech talks.

May 28, 11:00am - 4:00pm at Motorola Mobility, 222 W. Merchandise Mart Plaza, Suite 1800, Chicago,IL

Agenda and Activities: 

11:00-11:30 Welcome and check-in

11:30- 1:00 Google I/O Keynote Live Stream Viewing and Lunch

 1:30-2:00 Panel: I/O Keynote Highlights and Discussion "The year ahead in Tech" 

2:00 - 3:30 Tech Talks TBA

3:30 - 4:00 Networking and Wrap Up 

We are excited to celebrate with you! Please RSVP with your full name and names of your guests for badges and security. 

This event is FREE as_well_as Awesome!

Google I/O Website

Google I/O Chicago Extended on G+

events.name: Introduction to Unity on the Android Platform
events.description:
Interested in games? Come learn how to use Unity on the Android platform!

Corey Johnson from Unity and Kristan "Krispy" Uccello from Google will lead a Unity and Android code lab.  Learn the basics of developing a game in Unity and deploying it to Android phones and Android TVs. The code lab will provide an entry point into game development for beginners, and an overview of how Unity games run on the Android platform for current game developers.

Please bring your laptops with Unity Personal Edition, Android Studio and your favorite photo editor.

Agenda:

6:00 - 6:30 Food & Networking

6:30 - 8:30 Code Lab: Introduction to Unity and Deployment to Android Platforms

8:30 - 9:00 Discussion, Demos & Networking

About The Presenters:

Kristan "Krispy" Uccello: Krispy Uccello has been working in the technology sector for 20 years, for the last 4 years he has been part of the engineering teams at Google. He has founded and worked for startups as well, worked for large organizations such as Nortel Networks, Unilever and the FDA. Over the last three years Krispy has been working with the game developer industry to help being amazing game titles to the Android platform. Android TV gaming is of particular interest to Krispy.

Corey Johnson: Corey likes games, soccer, cookies, and pop culture. He desperately strives to do at least one of those for money. He isn't fit enough to play soccer competitively and not lazy enough to eat cookies and watch TV... at least not all day. So he's been in the game industry for the last 10 years doing everything from engine, tools, game play, UI, and network programming. For the last 3 years he's been traveling the globe helping people with Unity. Before that, he's been credited on dozens of titles at Electronic Arts and shipped Ultima Online: Kingdoms Reborn and Darkspore.

events.name: Launching and growing a startup on the Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
You are a developer with exciting ideas to launch online, and you want to be all set for success from the start? This session will introduce the Google Cloud Platform key components by replaying the past 5 years at SnapEngage on the Cloud Platform, adding components of the platform one by one to grow from an idea, to a feature and finally to a software as a service serving billions of queries every month. We will cover Google AppEngine, Google CloudStorage, Google BigQuery, Google Compute Engine and also mention some interesting non-Google developer products which complement the Cloud Platform. 

Agenda
6-6:30 - Networking

6:30-7:30 - Launching and growing a startup on the Google Cloud Platform Presented by Jerome Mouton

7:30-8 - Networking

About the Presenter: Jerome Mouton is a Google Developer Expert for The Google Cloud Platform. Jerome is the co-founder and CTO at SnapEngage, a customer engagement and live chat solution. He is also a lead for GDG Berlin. Previously, he founded LjmSite, a developer of gadgets for the web, on the Google Gadget platforms such as iGoogle, Orkut and AdWords. He has been using the Google AppEngine Python since 2008, and AppEngine Java from early 2009.

events.name: The Material and Immaterial Material of Material Design
events.description:
Agenda

6:00 - 6:30 Food and Socializing

6:30 - 7:30 The Material and Immaterial Material of Material Design by Jordan Beck

7:30 - 8:00 Socializing

The Material and Immaterial Material of Material Design

A lot has changed with Android design in the last five years. Most of those changes have been in the last year with the advent of Material Design. In this talk, Jordan will walk through some of the most common designs in Material and show examples of how you can use them to add personal identity to your apps.

Jordan has been developing Android apps for over five years. Previously, he was the first Android engineer to work at IFTTT (If This Then That) and is now the Senior Android Engineer at Rithmio, here in Chicago.

events.name: Efficient Architecture: Strategies for Reusable Code
events.description:
Efficient Architecture: Strategies for Reusable Code

About the talk: Ryan will describe strategies to identify good candidates for re-usability, how to create requirements to make the library useful, and steps to limit scope and ensure the library is useful without getting in the way. He will also discuss the importance of documenting reusable components, and treating the library like a client project. 

About the Speaker: Ryan Harter is a freelance Android developer, and Google Developer Expert, who’s been developing Android apps for over 5 years. He creates high quality apps that users love, like Fragment and Shift. When not coding, or writing about coding, Ryan enjoys playing guitar, snowboarding or skateboarding, depending on the Chicago weather, or spending time with his wife and dogs.

Agenda:

6:00-6:30 - Networking & Food
6:30-7:30 - Efficient Architecture: Strategies for Reusable Code by Ryan Harter

events.name: Android Marshmallow 6.0
events.description:
Come learn about all the fun new additions to Android in Android Marshmallow 6.0! And beer! cause beer goes with marshmallows!

Sponsored & Hosted by ContextMedia 

Agenda:

6-6:30 Socializing & Food

6:30-6:45 Announcements

6:45 - 7:45 Android Marshmallow 6.0 by Jeremy Shore

events.name: Genymotion for Application testing and Continuous Integration
events.description:
Two talks given by Genymotion - Genymotion for Application testing and Continuous Integration & Building your own AOSP

Genymotion for Application testing and Continuous Integration

How the new Genymotion command line tool and the Gradle plugin can help you run your automated tests? Integrate your virtual devices into your CI server, create the devices automatically, start them, run your tests, grab the logs then trash everything: every test should be done on a brand new device!

During this session, we will show you how to define your devices through the command line tool or in your Gradle script, when to run your test scripts, how to grab your logs and clean the place. We will also explain how to integrate those features into your preferred CI tool and make the best of it.

Then close your eyes, press the button, relax, the robots will do the work.

Building your own AOSP

Talk about how to download the source code, what’s in it, how to build it for nexus devices.

events.name: Building Revolutionary Realtime Applications With Firebase
events.description:
Abe Haskins, a Developer Programs Engineer at Google on the Firebase team is in town to talk Firebase with GDG Chicago. Come for the talk stay for the Tacos and Margaritas!

Agenda:

6-6:30 - Tacos, Margaritas and socializing

6:30-7:30 - Building Revolutionary Realtime Applications Presented by Abe Haskins

About the talk:

Building Revolutionary Realtime Applications: We'll focus on a technical discussion of why realtime matters to users and we'll discuss some of the current options for implementing realtime solutions.

About the speaker:

Abe Haskins is a Developer Programs Engineer at Google in SF on the Firebase team. Before working at Google he grew up and lived in the Midwest running a Firebase focused consulting company that worked with many of the largest companies using Firebase. Before that he contracted with Firebase doing open-source work, answering support and generally helping out where needed.

events.name: GDG Study Jam: Android For Beginners - Part 1 of 5
events.description:
Come join us for GDG Study Jam, a community organized study group around the Udacity Android for Beginners course. This will provide a group setting to get started with Android development.

The Study Jam consists of 5 2 hour sessions spread over 5 weeks. In each session we'll go over online course material together with room for questions and assistance. The course consists of 3 lessons with 2 practice sets, and a final project.

What you get

• Personal tutoring on the course material

• Community setting to support course learning

• Google offered Study Jams completion certificate 

• Discount on Android Nanodegree upon course completion 

• Opportunity to join Google Launchpad with completed app

Prior to starting the course, please register via the special Udacity Study Jams link.

events.name: Google I/O Extended 2016 at Motorola Mobility
events.description:
Join us for the biggest annual Google party! Google I/O Extended!

Please join Motorola Mobility, Google Developer Group Chicago and Google Developer Group Chicago West for Google I/O Extended Live at Motorola!

We will be streaming the Google I/O keynote, some live I/O talks and serving a light lunch. 

Wednesday, May 18, 10:30am - 3:30pm at Motorola, 222 W. Merchandise Mart Plaza, Suite 1800, Chicago,IL

10:30am - 11:45am - Networking and light lunch
12:00pm - 2:00pm - Live Stream Google I/O Keynote
2:15pm - 3:00pm - Live Stream What's New in Android 

Please read these important event restrictions and details before you register: 

1. You must provide your full first and last name when registering and bring a government issued ID otherwise you will not be issued a badge and will not be allowed into the event.

2. You must arrive before 11:45am for security purposes.  No one will be allowed into the event after 11:45 

3. You may bring food and drinks to the event, but you cannot leave and come back.  

4. You will be asked to sign an NDA 

Thank you for respecting the Motorola facilities and security by complying with the above!

This event is FREE as_well_as Awesome!
Google I/O Website
events.how_to_find_us: Take the Motorola Elevators in the Merchandise Mart to the 18th Floor and you will be ushered to the event space

events.name: Post Google I/O Meetup with GDG Chicago West: Live Firebase Platform Overview
events.description:
Joint Meetup with Google Developer Group Chicago West at their new home, Level 257, the Namco - Themed Arcade and Restaurant in Woodfield Mall in Schaumburg

Join us on May 26th from 5:00pm to 8:00pm for a Live Hangout to see Googlers discuss the Firebase Platform recently announced at Google I/O and get a chance to ask them questions live through Google Hangouts, and a Post Google I/O Review and Chat!

Agenda 

5:00 - 7:00 Live Hangout 

7:00 - 8:00 Post I/O Chat 

 8:00 - Networking and socializing, game playing and bowling!

Please register at www.bit.ly/registerLH so that you can ask questions during the Live Hangout.

Dinner orders can be placed during the event.

Please RSVP to this event if you are planning to come. Also please feel free to reshare this to anyone or circle that you think may be interested.

Hope to see you there!﻿

events.name: Google Cloud Platform Use Cases, Containers, Automation, and Microservices
events.description:
Join us to learn about using Google Cloud Platform tools and services.  Motorola Mobility will be describing use cases for GCP and Sandeep Dinesh from Google will be talking about scaling microservices using gRPC, Kubernetes, and Containers.  

Agenda:

6:00 - 6:30 - Registration, Food, and Networking
6:30 - 7:00 - Motorola Mobility talk about using Google Cloud Platform
7:00 - 8:00 - Sandeep Dinesh presenting Scaling Microservices using gRPC, Kubernetes, and Containers
8:00 - 8:30 - Networking

events.name: Progressive Web App Summit
events.description:
Progressive Web App Summit!

Join us for an evening full of web workshops and learning about new web technologies.

Progressive Web Apps, Serverless, Web Components, have you kept up with the wave of new stuff?

Google Developer Group Chicago will introduce you to the latest and greatest including code labs on Progressive Web Apps, Firebase, Polymer web components, Node.js on Google App Engine, Firebase hosting, and introduction to serverless application development. 

Bring your laptop and instructions will be sent prior to the meetup to set up your environment

6:00-6:30 Food and Networking

6:30-7:15 Introductions to PWA, Firebase, Web Components, and Serverless Application Development

7:15 - 8:00 Codelab and workshop, build a progressive web app with Firebase and Web Components

8:00-8:30 - Deployment with Node.js on Google App Engine and Firebase hosting

Speakers:
Valerie Scarlata and Jeremy Shore, Google Developer Group Chicago
Codelab Coaches:
 Dan Baran and Sergei Kozyrenko, Google Developer Group Chicago

events.name: Progressive Web App Roadshow
events.description:
Progressive Web App Roadshow is coming to Chicago!

Please register for this event via Google Registration Link: DO NOT RSVP on Meetup

https://events.withgoogle.com/pwa-roadshow-north-america/registrations/new/

Progressive Web Apps are experiences that combine the best of the web and the best of apps. They load quickly, even on flaky networks, can re-engage with users by sending web push notifications, have an icon on the home screen and load as top-level, full screen experiences.

At this event, we'll explain the what, why and how of Progressive Web Apps, and work through some code labs to give you some hands-on experience (bring your laptop!)

Please join us to learn about the future of the web with Progressive Web Apps, why they are important and how to build and deploy them effectively.

Please register for this event via Google Registration Link: Do Not RSVP on Meetup

https://events.withgoogle.com/pwa-roadshow-north-america/registrations/new/

GDG Chicago will see you there!

events.name: 2016 Chicago User Group Holiday Party

venue.name: Braintree
venue.address_1: 222 W Merchandise Mart Plaza, Floor 8, Chicago, IL 60654

events.description:
NOTE:

The event appears to be full on Eventbrite so we are closing RSVPs on Meetup. There appears to be a waitlist available and we would encourage folks still interested in attending to register for the waitlist on Eventbrite!

RSVP at the Eventbrite page: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/2016-user-group-holiday-party-tickets-28526926806


Event Details (from the event organizers): 

Kick off the Holiday Season with the local USER GROUP HOLIDAY PARTY with a fun event at Braintree sponsored by Gogo on December 7th, 2016.  Sponsors will be handing out and raffling SWAG (Shirts, Tiles, Solar Chargers, 3 way USB Cords, and much more), plus we will be raffling off a MICROSOFT SURFACE PRO computer.

Join us and enjoy some great food, drinks and conversation. Members of the Schaumburg .NET, Chicago .NET, Illinois Java, Geekfest, Docker, The Chicago Cloud Computing Meetup Group, Apache Flink, OWASP/Security, Coding while Black, Chicago .NET Mobile, Graph Database Chicago, Chicago Java, and Chicago Women Developers, AWS Chicago Suburbs, Chicago DevOps, Google Developers user groups and the local Conference community will be there, it is great chance to hear about lots of exciting developer and software events taking place in Chicago in 2017.  Its also a great time to network and build connections that can help your career!

This event is sponsored by Gogo, Braintree, Microsoft, Chicago Coder Conference and other sponsors to be announced.

We look forward to seeing you there!

Again, make sure to RSVP on Eventbrite!

events.name: Firebase Summit Extended/Codelab
events.description:
Come join GDG Chicago and learn more about Firebase. We will watch some highlights from the Firebase Summit that took place last month.

Afterwards Jeremy Shore will lead a Firebase Web codelab and talk about some of his experiences with Firebase.

Agenda:
6-6:30 Food, Drinks & Socializing
6:30 - 7:00 Keynote
7:00 - 8:00 Codelab

This codelab does require some setup on your computer. Since this is for web all you really need is npm and a text editor. I would highly recommend installing these two, and you should be ready to go:

IDE: https://code.visualstudio.com/

Node: https://nodejs.org/en/

events.name: Get talking with Actions on Google
events.description:
Let your users be the voice talent with Actions on Google. Learn how to design, develop, and distribute rich conversational experiences or direct action commands. We’ll show you how to approach voice-driven, natural language interactions with API.AI’s powerful bot platform.

Agenda:
6-6:30 Food and Drink
6:30-7:30 Abraham Williams & Pearl Latteier Present "Get Talking With Actions on Google"

About the speakers:
Abraham Williams

An experienced developer and start-up founder, Abraham Williams brings a broad range of skills to his current role as a senior developer at Bendyworks. A top 1% contributor at Stack Overflow and an active member of Google Developer Groups, Abraham has been recognized by Google as a Developer Expert for his ability to identify technology problems and provide quality solutions in the community.

Pearl Latteier

Pearl Latteier is a software engineer at Bendyworks in Madison WI. For the past several years, she has focused primarily on building data-intensive JavaScript applications for web and mobile, most recently with React JS and React Native. She is also experienced with server-side technologies including Node, Ruby on Rails, and PHP. Before becoming a software developer, Pearl earned a PhD in from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where for five years she taught courses in the Department of Communication Arts.

About the talk:
Let your users be the voice talent with Actions on Google. Learn how to design, develop, and distribute rich conversational experiences or direct action commands. We’ll show you how to approach voice-driven, natural language interactions with API.AI’s powerful bot platform.

events.name: GCP Next Extended
events.description:
Join GDG Chicago as we celebrate and learn about the exciting announcements at Google Cloud Next! We will start off with some food and networking. We will then kick off with highlights from the event last week and transition to an open panel discussion.

Afterwards, Joel Vasallo will lead a Google Cloud code lab showing of some pieces of Google Cloud, such as Container Engine, Cloud Shell, and more!

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:30 Food, Drinks, and Networking
6:30 - 7:15 Announcement Recap/Panel
7:15 - 8:30 Code Lab

Due to the nature of this running on Google Cloud, you will need an account and also bring a computer. We encourage folks to pair up, or work together through the Code Lab if you wish to participate live! Don't have an account? Fear not! New users can register and receive $300.00 in credits (which last 12 months), and also you can leverage the Always Free tier.

The materials for the code lab will be made available after the meetup as well; for you to follow on your own time as well!

Hope to see you there!

events.name: Chicago Roboto Android Conference
events.description:
Please register here

Act fast! The first 15 people to register with discount code GDGChicago will get 40% off their ticket price. At $399, Chicago Roboto is a great deal, saving 40% makes it an amazing deal. If you miss that, you still have a chance to be one of the 15 to save 20% off your ticket if you use the discount code GDGChicago20.

With 28 speakers presenting and more than 25 sessions over two days, Chicago Roboto is going to be an amazing event. This awesome conference is right here in town, show your support so it can come back next year and every year after that!

Chicago Roboto is bringing speakers from around the world to town, come learn from some of the best in the industry!

Can't make it to Chicago Roboto? Make sure to come to GDG Chicago on April 20th to see Dave Smith talk about IoT

events.name: Weaving Together IoT Devices
events.description:
Agenda:
5:30-6:00: Food, Networking, and Announcements
6:00-7:00 Weaving Together IoT Devices Presented by Dave Smith, a Developer Advocate at Google, focused on IoT and the Android Things platform.

About the talk:
Google Weave is an open communications platform designed to provide a consistent language for smart devices to connect with apps and Google services. It is tailored to long-tail device makers who wish to take an IoT product to market without building their own cloud infrastructure. We will explore the Weave platform and how developers can get started using it to build connected devices.

About the Presenter:
Dave Smith is a Developer Advocate at Google, focused on IoT and the Android Things platform. Over the past decade he has worked with low power M2M systems and wireless radio links, and also built custom applications and system components to run Android on embedded platforms. He has a passion for finding opportunities to make devices, and developers, smarter.

Dave will also be talking at a great Android conference in town called Chicago Roboto. Check it out at http://www.chicagoroboto.com

events.name: Google I/O 2017 Extended
events.description:
Come join us for I/O Extended as we discuss all of the happenings at Google's big developer event Google I/O. This year we are doing it a bit differently and doing it after the fact. We will have a panel and show some clips from the keynote and/or talks. We will also have food and drinks!

We will cover a bunch of exciting announcements and news around topics such as:
- Kotlin x Android
- PWAs x AMP
- Firebase
- Tensorflow/ML
- much more

Hope to see you all there!

Agenda:
5:30-6:00 Food, Drinks, Networking & Announcements
6:00-7:15 Panel Discussion w/ video clips of I/O
7:15-7:30 Wrap up

events.name: Google Cloud Spanner: Worldwide Consistent Database At Scale
events.description:
A worldwide consistent database that is fully managed. What is this database you speak of? It is a product from Google called Cloud Spanner. 

Join us as we host Joe Intrakamhang, Solutions Engineer at Google, speak about one of the coolest new technologies in GCP: Cloud Spanner! The talk will have an overview, how Cloud Spanner works, and wrapped up with awesome demo.

Hope to see you all there! 

Agenda: 
5:30-6:00 Food, Drinks, Networking & Announcements 
6:00-7:15 Talk by Joe Intrakamhang
7:15-7:30 Wrap up

events.name: gRPC 101 for Java Developers - building fast and efficient microservices
events.description:
Agenda:
5:30-6 Networking
6-6:15 Opening and Announcements
6:15-7:15 Ray Tsang - Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform - gRPC 101 for Java Developers - building fast and efficient microservices

About the Talk
gRPC is a high performance, open source, general RPC framework that puts mobile and HTTP/2 first. gRPC is based on many years of Google's experience in building distributed systems - it is designed to be low latency, bandwidth and CPU efficient, to create massively distributed systems that span data centers, as well as power mobile apps, real-time communications, IoT devices and APIs. It's also interoperable between multiple languages.

But beyond that fact that it's more efficient than REST, we'll look into how to use gRPC's streaming API, where you can establish server-side streaming, client-side streaming, and bidirectional streaming! This allows developers to build sophisticated real-time applications with ease.

In addition to learning about gRPC and HTTP/2 concepts with code and demonstrations, we'll also deep dive into integration with existing build systems such as Maven and Gralde, but also frameworks such as Spring Boot and RxJava.
- Configuring projects to generate gRPC stub code
- Using Protobuf3 to define services
- Creating synchronous and asynchronous services, with streaming
. - Load balancing
- Interceptors

About The Speaker
Ray is a Developer Advocate for the Google Cloud Platform. Ray had extensive hands on cross-industry enterprise systems integration delivery and management experiences since 2002. Ray has built mobile applications & micropayment systems as an independent contractor. During his time in Taiwan, Ray has built IT systems for Taiwanese government for a large scale search engine, electronic customs record management, and more. At Accenture, Ray was a team lead for a SOA deployment at a utilities company, building out common frameworks for messaging and service tracing. Moreover, Ray was an architect leading teams to implement online booking channels for a global hospitality company. During Ray's time at Red Hat, he was specialized in Java middleware, and contributing to open source projects such as Infinispan.

Aside from technology, Ray enjoys traveling and adventures. Ray is currently a Developer Advocate at Google. Follow Ray on Twitter @saturnism

events.name: Lightning Talks
events.description:
Please join us at 1871 for an evening of 4 Lightning Talks (10-15 minutes) from YOU; our community! We can't wait to hear about all your great topics. Thanks everyone who submitted talk proposals to the event!

Schedule:

6:00PM - Doors open*, Snacks, Socializing and Networking

6:30PM - Announcements, and Begin Lightning Talks

~7:30PM - Closing Announcements and End Lightning Talks 

Speakers:

• Doug Campbell - Setting Sail with Spinnaker

• Teodora Szasz - Istio

• Cody Engel - Model View Intent in Android

• Matthew Wojtowicz - Angular 2 Authentication

events.name: Writing Your First App for Google Home
events.description:
Join us in welcoming Martin Omander talk about Writing Your First App for Google Home!

Google Home is a voice-activated speaker powered by the Google Assistant. While the Assistant is good at answering general questions, you can make Google Home even smarter by building your own app for it and publishing that app to the world. In this session we will go through the steps to do just that, including how to tune the AI, starting from a blank slate.

Martin Omander works for Google in Mountain View, California. His job in the Developer Relations team is to support awesome developer communities, like the Google Developer Groups. On his spare time he manages to sneak in some programming, usually writing HTML5 apps running on top of Firebase. Before Google, Martin worked at string of startups in Silicon Valley as a software engineer.

Agenda:
5:45-6:15: Food, Drinks, Networking & Announcements
6:15-7:00: Writing Your First App for Google Home by Martin Omander
7:00-7:15: Wrap up

events.name: Privet Kotlin
events.description:
What is this Kotlin thing that I’ve been hearing about? Why should I care about it? How do I read and write this non-verbose code? All of those questions and more will be answered in less than an hour. This is a crash course into Kotlin and we’ll also share techniques for convincing your coworkers to learn about Kotlin.

Come join GDG Chicago as Cody Engel and Nick Cruz discuss Kotlin!

Agenda:

6-6:30 Networking
6:30-6:45 Announcements
6:45-7:30 Privet Kotlin Presented by Cody Engel and Nick Cruz

About the Speakers:
Cody Engel: Cody Engel is a Senior Android Engineer at Yello. He has focused on system design, writing clean code, and mentoring others. Outside of work Cody is typically working on a side project, exploring the city, or playing video games. 

Nick Cruz: Nick Cruz is an Android Developer at Yello. He has a passion for writing clean code and crisp animations. On a given weekend, you can find Nick tending to his plants or training for his next triathlon.

Windy City DevFest is a 100% community organized developer conference with industry experts presenting on exciting topics including mobile, web, cloud, virtual reality, machine learning, and much more!

events.name: Building Augmented Reality Apps With JavaScript
events.description:
With the recent introductions of ARKit on iOS and ARCore on Android, developers are using augmented reality to create a new wave of innovative applications—as well as a lot of really stupid stuff.

The first thing we’re going to do is demo all of those apps, because I think you need to know they exist—for science. Once that’s done we’ll talk about the ARKit and ARCore APIs on the off chance you might use them to build something that is genuinely useful. Seriously though, augmented reality is really cool so it’s worth knowning the basics, and we’ll cover those to get you up to speed. When your coworkers ask about the latest hit AR app to hit the stores you’ll be able to act knowledgable and stuff.

This talk’s demos will use NativeScript—a project that lets you build native iOS and Android apps using JavaScript and frameworks like Angular and Vue. NativeScript offers a path forward for JavaScript developers interested in building in AR, so if you’re a JS developer you should feel right at home, but we’ll also discuss the raw ARKit and ARCore APIs for those of you comfortable working in native iOS and Android apps.

Come learn what the augmented reality hype is all about, and how you can building AR apps yourself!

Agenda:

6-6:30 - Food and Announcements

6:30-7:30 - TJ VanToll presents Building Augmented Reality Apps With JavaScript

About The Speaker

TJ VanToll is a front-end developer, author, and a Principal Developer Advocate for Progress (https://www.progress.com/). TJ has over a decade of web development experience, including a few years working on the jQuery team. Nowadays, he spends his time helping web developers build mobile apps through projects like NativeScript (https://www.nativescript.org/).

events.name: Google Cloud Study Jam: GCP Essentials, Docker, and Kubernetes
events.description:
• What we'll do
Want to get started on the Google Cloud, but don't know where to begin?

Join us for our Cloud Study Jam! Together we'll work through three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs, then you will get free access to the next quest so you can finish this series of labs at home to get a Google-hosted badge for your online profile. You will be able to get hands-on experience with Docker, Kubernetes and Scientific Data Processing, which will earn you additional badges.

Join this meetup to get official Google training, a $70+ value, free of charge.

Bring a laptop (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of the popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed.

Agenda:
5:30pm: Food and Networking
6:00pm: Three Google Cloud Platform Essentials labs
7:30pm: Break
8:00pm: Intro to Docker or Scientific Data Processing lab
9:00pm: Event ends

• What to bring
Laptop (PC, Mac, Chromebook)

events.name: Spotlight on Women Techmakers: Entrepreneurship in Tech
events.description:
This workshop is the kickoff of our series: Women Techmakers powered by GDG Chicago. This series is focused on promoting an environment of inclusion for women in technology, as well as celebrating women leading the industry. All tech enthusiasts at any skill level are encouraged to join us in learning, teaching, and networking with others.

We have two amazing speakers for this month; Melissa McSherry (https://www.melissamcsherry.net) and Awatif Yahya (https://www.awehorizons.com).

Speaker: Melissa McSherry, Leadership Coach
Bio:
Melissa is a mentor at the renowned Chicago tech hub 1871. An entrepreneur since 2010, she has launched two successful business, doubled her monthly income, and created a true life by design, all while raising a six-year-old son. She has been the guest on numerous podcasts including “The Brave Entrepreneur” with Jena Rodriguez, “The Weekly Parady” with Heather Parady, and “Learn Grown Earn” with Mike Szczesniak.

Talk Title: Prioritizing Primary Profit Avenues
Description:
Join us as Melissa McSherry (author, leadership coach, and speaker) shares her expertise on how to succeed in tech entrepreneurship and walks us through 5 Profit Priority Points. These include getting clear on, and connecting to, your goals, realistic time management, and creating a concrete plan of action to success. Your business has huge potential. Sometimes, it seems hard to reach that potential, because you feel buried under all the things you believe you need to do to be successful. The fastest path through stress and overwhelm, and to experience proﬁt and freedom, is when you have a crystal clear Proﬁt Priority Plan, designed to create results fast for your unique business.

If you’ve ever dreamed of joining the world of tech startups or are looking to increase your side-hustle and freelance game, this workshop is for you! Learn how to escape from the traditional 9 to 5 and get exactly what you want from entrepreneurship...and from life. Sign up now to get what you want from the tech industry and the time to enjoy it.

Speaker: Awatif Yahya
Bio:
Awatif Yahya started her career in IT with a BSc in Information Technology from Leeds University, U.K, then pivoted to business functions, and obtained an MBA through a Fulbright Scholarship. She has fifteen years of industry work experience; ten of which are with British American Tobacco where her last role was Head of HR sitting on the executive board.

Awatif is passionate about organizations that are inspiring, motivating, safe and fun workplaces. She would like to see more organizations take the lead in employee development and engagement. For that reason, she channels her passion, academic training and work experience by offering workshops to business managers and entrepreneurs empowering them with the necessary tools to create productive and healthy work places.

She wants to share her knowledge and experiences to help both companies and their employees reach new horizons where tranquility exists between life and work. This is the mission of her company, Awe Horizons.

Talk Title: Leadership Skills Workshop
Description:
Understanding what leadership is, what it is not, and discussing the difference between leadership and dictatorship. The workshop will address the role of emotional intelligence in effective leadership, and dive into three leadership categories: People Leadership, Business Leadership and Strategic Leadership. There will be a fun activity to get participants off their seats and engaged with the topic.

GDG Chicago: https://twitter.com/chicagogdg
Women Techmakers: https://www.womentechmakers.com/
Code of Conduct and Community Guidelines: https://developers.google.com/programs/community/gdg/resources/

events.name: Google I/O 2018 Extended: I/O Recap
events.description:
Come join us for I/O Extended as we discuss all of the happenings at Google's big developer event Google I/O. This year we are doing it a bit differently and doing it after the fact. We will have a panel and show some clips from the keynote and/or talks. During the panel, we will talk about various announcements and the impact they have. We will also have food and drinks (maybe more ;) )!

Our Panelists are:
Brittney Braxton is a software developer at Healthcare Service Corporation and co-leader of the Chicago chapter of Girl Develop It. She enjoys crafting, coding, and cats, all while enjoying a good cup of tea. Brittney strives to connect with folks who geek out over code with hopes to contribute to a friendly and inviting tech community.

Arelia Jones is a web developer at Sprout Social, co-leader of the Chicago Chapter of Girl Develop It, and co-founder and instructor at CoderSpace where she teaches web development to high school students. She has a lifelong passion for the web and enjoys learning and helping others learn more about technology.

Jerrell Mardis is a Google Developer Expert for Android, a Lead Android Engineer at Salesforce.com, and an organizer for the popular Chicago Roboto Android conference. He’s been developing apps for Android since Android 2.0 and is passionate about building beautiful and functional Android apps that exceed users’ expectations.

Jeremy Shore is a Software Engineer at GoHealth and a co-organizer for GDG Chicago. He has a strong passion for learning, development, and design. Personally, he does a lot of work with technologies like Kubernetes, Web, Firebase, and Android.

We will cover a bunch of exciting announcements and news!

Agenda:
5:30-6:00 Food, Drinks, Networking & Announcements
6:00-7:15 Panel Discussion w/ video clips of I/O
7:15-7:30 Wrap up

events.name: Build Actions for Your Community
events.description:
“Build Actions for Your Community” is an open and modular event designed by Google and offered to you our community. We will offer opportunities for developers attending the event to learn how to build Actions for the Google Assistant that are useful for your community - whether it's a professional network, interest group, or your hometown. Together, we can build something in an area that you care about or are interested in! We can't wait to see you there!

Join us as Jeremy Wilken, an expert on all things Google Assistant, walks through some of the exciting capabilities available when building your own actions for the Google Assistant and help you get started.

Agenda
6:00 - Food & networking
6:30 - Welcome & announcements
6:45 - Build Your Own Voice Interface with Google Actions Presented by Jeremy Wilken

Build Your Own Voice Interface with Google Actions

Learn how to create your own voice interfaces using the Google Actions platform. We'll look at the technologies involved, how to plan for a conversation, and then build a voice interaction together.

With the rise of voice assistants, voice is becoming another surface area for users to interact with your product or service. We can now start to blend this new technology with our existing offerings to improve user experience, engagement, and satisfaction.

About the Speaker:
Jeremy Wilken is a software engineer and Google Developer Expert for Angular and the Google Assistant. He is the author of Angular in Action and Ionic in Action, as well as a regular speaker at events around the world. Jeremy lives in Austin, Texas, with his wife and daughters. When he isn't coding, you can find him brewing beer.

events.name: Connect and visualize all of your data with Google Data Studio
events.description:
Agenda:
5:30-6:00PM Food and drinks
6:00-6:15PM Announcements
6:15-7:00PM Connect and visualize all of your data with Google Data Studio Presented by Minhaz Kazi, Developer Advocate at Google
(Might add in a short code lab please check back closer to the event)

About the talk:
Data Studio is Google’s next generation business intelligence and visualization platform that allows you to fetch data from a variety of sources and create shareable reports and dashboards, all for free. Learn how to visualize data from any internet enabled source in Data Studio by leveraging Google Apps Script to build your own custom Community Connector. By creating and publishing your own Community Connector, you can provide a push button visualization platform to your organization as well as your users.

About the speaker:
Minhaz Kazi is the Developer Advocate for Google Data Studio. As a business intelligence veteran, Minhaz is always exploring new ways for developers to collect, analyze, and visualize data. He is available for long discussions on circular reference errors, benefits of pie charts, SQL commas, and design of everyday things.

events.name: Google Cloud NEXT Extended 2018
events.description:
Join GDG Chicago as we celebrate and learn about the exciting announcements at Google Cloud Next (https://cloudnext.withgoogle.com/)! We will start off with some food and networking. We will then kick off with highlights from the event last week and transition to an open panel discussion.

Agenda:
6:00 - 6:30 Food, Drinks, and Networking
6:30 - 8:00 Announcement Recap/Panel

Get started with Google Cloud today! Don't have an account? Fear not! New users can register (https://cloud.google.com/free/) and receive $300.00 in credits (which last 12 months), and also you can leverage the Always Free tier (https://cloud.google.com/free/).

events.name: Workshop: Introduction to Kotlin & TornadoFX
events.description:
***Hands-on Kotlin & TornadoFX Workshop Setup: http://bit.ly/2npehbC

In a world where everyone and their mother uses web development, a quiet grassroots movement is bringing back native development. Whether you're brand-new to coding, or you just have framework fatigue, native desktop development can be used to create internal solutions in lieu of needless/repetitive work across any industry. TornadoFX is so easy and fun to pick up anyone could get into coding while simultaneously automating solutions in their everyday work.

TornadoFX is a great way to start learning Kotlin without being bogged down by servers or mobile or web development. You're not required to know JavaFX to start native application development, and there's a plethora of material out there.

Come join us in creating a scheduling application for the neighborhood cat-sitter, who needs to keep track feeding up to 8 cats on any given day.

Bring a laptop if you can!

Bio:
Amanda Hinchman-Dominguez, Software Engineer at Yello, is a Grinnell '17 alum from the sunny state of Florida. Merely at the beginning but specializes in UI development producing large-scale projects in sales enablement.

Experienced in data-driven development and analysis in social inquiry, native, web, and Android development. More notably a sculpture artist.

Agenda:
6:00 - Food & networking
6:30 - Welcome & announcements
6:45 - Introduction to Kotlin & TornadoFX with Amanda Hinchman-Dominguez

events.name: Introduction to Angular 6
events.description:
Alain Chautard will go through an introduction to the Angular framework. If you don't know anything about Angular, this is a perfect opportunity to learn all of the basics and get you started with the framework! Alain will talk about TypeScript, components, services, pipes, and how to work with Angular CLI through live coding. You will see that it is now easier than ever to add front-end development to your skillset!

Alain is a Google Developer Expert in Web Technologies / Angular. He started working with Angular JS in 2011.
Since then he has worked with all Angular versions on a daily basis, both as a developer and as a technical trainer.
He is the organizer of the Sacramento Angular Meetup group, co-organizer of the Google Developer Group chapter in Sacramento, California, conference speaker and published author of the Packt video course “Getting Started with Angular“.

events.name: Cloud Computing and Running Your Code on Google Cloud
events.description:
Agenda:
6-6:30 Food/Drinks and Socializing
6:30-7:15 Cloud computing and Running your code on Google Cloud Presented by Wesley Chun, Google Developer Advocate

Description:
Cloud computing has taken over industry by storm, yet there are still those confused by what it means. Is it getting VMs and your stack running on it? Is it switching from Microsoft Word to Google Docs? What if I'm a developer who wants to avoid doing DevOps work and just get my code online and accessible globally as quickly as possible? It's all of the above! This session begins with a (believe it or not) vendor-agnostic, high-level overview of cloud computing, including its three primary service levels. This is followed by an overview of Google Cloud, its GCP & G Suite developer platforms, and which products serve at which cloud service levels. Specifically, attendees will learn how to run code on serverless platforms. Code samples will be in Python & JavaScript, but other languages are supported. Time-permitting, we'll also discuss some of the GCP Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence tools.

Bio:
WESLEY CHUN (@wescpy) is the author of Prentice Hall's bestselling "Core Python" (corepython.com) series, co-author of "Python Web Development with Django" (withdjango.com), and has written for Linux Journal, CNET, and InformIT. In addition to being an engineer & Developer Advocate at Google focused on Google Cloud, and one of the hosts of the G Suite Dev Show (goo.gl/JpBQ40), Wesley runs CyberWeb (cyberwebconsulting.com), a consultancy specializing in Python training. Wesley has over 25 years of programming, teaching, and writing experience, and was one of the original Yahoo!Mail engineers. He holds degrees in CS, Math, and Music from the University of California, and is a Fellow of the Python Software Foundation.

events.name: Unveiling Your Voice with Strength: A Spotlight on Women Techmakers IWD Event

venue.name: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Illinois

events.description:
"Learn how to take advantage of the excellent personal and professional opportunities that result from public speaking in the tech ecosystem."

Agenda:
5:30-6 Food/Drinks and Socializing
6-7:30 Public Speaking Panel
7:30-8 Audience Q&A

Hear from an expert panel of experienced professional women in the tech industry as they provide actionable advice on converting your expertise into thought leadership and public speaking. Panelists will share timely advice and personal experiences on how to deliver your message to a wide variety of audiences. This event will help you figure out what your presentation should (or should not) include, provide tips on engaging your audience and feature candid discussions on presenting your expertise with confidence.

As part of GDG Chicago’s Spotlight on WomenTechmaker’s series, this International Women's Day (IWD) event features the encouragement, tools, and enthusiasm to bring much-needed diversity to technical events and the global tech conference stage. The event will be most useful to those who are interested in speaking at technical events or presenting at conferences, but everyone is welcome. We welcome attendees of all backgrounds and aim to create a truly inclusive event reflective of different perspectives.

Panelists include:
Natalie Brooks Powell, Manager and Leader of IBM's Global Business Services
Jeanne Cuff, Associate Director at ISG-One
Laura Janusek, Chief Product Officer and founding team member at Modern Teacher
Caroline Schiff, Local Marketing Producer at General Assembly Chicago
Hema Raj Trukenbrod, Founder and CEO of Pedia Source

Moderators:
Heather Conklin, Sr Developer at HCSC
Katie Prizy, Sr DevOps Engineer at HCSC

Panel Topics include:
Overcoming hesitancy towards speaking
Identifying your speaking goals
How to handle unexpected events
Networking and partnering with colleagues for presentations
Selecting the appropriate format (panels, solo, workshops)
Personal experiences (the good, the bad...the ugly)
Upcoming opportunities for public speaking events

“Unveiling your voice with strength” is part of GDG Chicago’s celebration of International Women’s Day. Sponsors include Google Developer Groups, WomenTechmakers, HCSC.

Share on Social Media: #WTM19 #WomenTechmakers #WTMChicago #GDGChicago

events.name: I/O Extended 2019
events.description:
Come learn from attendees of Google's I/O their thoughts and feedback on Google's new features. You will hear great devs, and product managers from around the city how the new features and products will impact the applications going forward.

We will have a panel and show some clips from the keynote and/or talks. During the panel, we will talk about various announcements and the impact they have. We will also have food and drinks (maybe more ;) )!

Our I/O Extended Panelists are:
Dan Baran

Joel Vasello

Jeremy Shore

Jerrell Mardis

with special guest moderator Laura Janusek, Chief Product Officer and founding team member at Modern Teacher!

We will cover a bunch of exciting announcements and news!

Agenda:
6:00-6:30 Food, Drinks, Networking & Announcements
6:30-7:45 Panel Discussion w/ video clips of I/O
7:45-8:00 Wrap up

events.name: Intro to Flutter: Is Flutter truly that easy?
events.description:
Agenda:
6-6:30 Food, Drinks and Socializing
6:30-7:15 Is Flutter truly that easy? Presented by Jorge Coca

About the talk:
If you are developer, chances are that you’ve heard about Flutter, either at Google I/O, or one of your colleagues told you about, or you’ve read a Medium article… but, what’s all this fuzz? Isn’t Flutter yet another cross platform promising a single codebase that can run anywhere? Pufff, we’ve seen that already, and it never works…
… except that this time IT WORKS! And not only for mobile apps, but also for desktop and web apps! In this talk, let me show how easy it is to get a Flutter app up and running, explore some of the core concepts of the framework and understand why this time Flutter is the truly “write once, run everywhere” framework.

About the speaker:
Jorge Coca is a spanish engineer lost in Chicago. He is writing the book "Dart 2 In Action" for Manning Publications. He works at BMW, in the mobile core team, developing the Connected experiences for BMW and MINI. Prior to that, he was the Android dev. Now, he is the Flutter dev. he loves working with the community, and has the pleasure of running the Chicago Flutter Meetup, where we work all together to build a welcoming environment for everyone interested in Flutter and Dart.

events.name: Intro to Google Maps Platform & Building data visualizations with Google Maps
events.description:
Agenda
6:00-6:30 Food/Socializing

6:30 - 7:00 - Intro to Google Maps Platform Presented by Angela Yu, Developer Advocate for Google Maps Platform

7:00 - 7:30 - Building awesome data visualization on the web with Google Maps Platform and Deck.gl presented by Alex Muramoto, Developer Advocate for Google Maps Platform

Title: Intro to Google Maps Platform
Abstract: In this talk well give an overview of the Google Maps Platform, it's APIs and SDKs as well as interesting facts about the geo data the platform provides.
Bio: Angela Yu is a developer advocate for Google Maps Platform. Throughout her career, she has geeked out on voice recognition, mobile app development, and IoT. You can find her trapped in escape rooms or on Twitter.

Title: Building awesome data visualization on the web with Google Maps Platform and Deck.gl
Abstract: The Google team recently announced initial support for the Deck.gl framework, which brings beautiful, high volume, WebGL accelerated data visualization capabilities to maps. In this talk we'll look at how to integrate Deck.gl into maps on the web using the Maps JS API.
Bio: Alex Muramoto is a Developer Advocate for Google Maps Platform. At this point, his life has been pretty much consumed by JS, open-source, and way too much documentation.

events.name: Introduction to Kotlin: Kotlin Koans Workshop
events.description:
PLEASE BRING YOUR COMPUTER FOR THE WORKSHOP

Agenda:
6-6:30 Food/Socializing/Announcements
6:30-7:30 Introduction to Kotlin: Kotlin Koans Workshop - Led by: Jonathan Bisson and Uddyami Agrawal

About the Speakers:
Jonathan Bisson is a Research Assistant Professor at UIC in the College of Pharmacy. His work is a mixture of drug discovery from natural products (pharmacognosy) and software development. He started using Kotlin around two years ago and it his now his major language (accompanied by a good deal of Python for all the graphics and statistics).

Uddyami Agrawal is an Android Developer with Raise Marketplace. She is serial startup product engineer who specializes in rapid prototyping. She has seen multiple apps, complete their lifecycle from inception to live date. She has done mostly mobile production code but is passionate about full stack development. Kotlin being the new tool she is obsessed with.

About the Workshop:
This tutorial walks you through a series of exercises to get familiar with Kotlin.

Kotlin Koans are a series of exercises to get you familiar with the Kotlin Syntax. Each exercise is created as a failing unit test and your job is to make it pass. You can work with Kotlin Koans in one of three ways.

You can play with Koans online (https://play.kotlinlang.org/koans).
You can solve the tasks right inside IntelliJ IDEA or Android Studio by installing the EduTools plugin (https://www.jetbrains.com/help/education/install-edutools-plugin.html) and choosing Kotlin Koans course (https://www.jetbrains.com/help/education/learner-start-guide.html?section=Kotlin%20Koans).
You can clone the project on GitHub (https://github.com/Kotlin/kotlin-koans). You can open this project in IntelliJ IDEA, or work with it from the command line using your favourite editor. Note that to work with Koans from Android Studio, use the EduTools plugin.

Whatever way you choose to solve koans, you can see the solution for each task. In the online version and inside EduTools plugin you'll find the button "Show answer". The GitHub repository has two branches, master which contains the exercises for you to do and resolutions which contains the resolved exercises. We recommend checking the solution after you implement the task to compare your solution with the proposed one. Make sure you don't cheat!

events.name: Kotlin/Everywhere
events.description:
Get Tickets and RSVP @ http://chicago.kotlineverywhere.com

KOTLIN/Everywhere is a series of community-led events, in collaboration with JetBrains and Google, where you can learn the essentials and best practices of Kotlin in Android, Google Cloud Platform, and multi-platform development.

Get Tickets and RSVP @ http://chicago.kotlineverywhere.com

Sign up to be a speaker at Kotlin Everywhere: https://www.papercall.io/kotlin-everywhere-chicago

events.name: Get Comfortable With Flutter by Peeking Under the Hood, by Andrew Brogdon
events.description:
Details
Most Flutter devs know that Widgets are an immutable configuration for a piece of app UI. But how does that configuration actually get consumed? And how does Flutter efficiently update your app's interface when you rebuild widgets? In this talk, you'll look beyond the widget tree to elements, state objects, and render objects, and learn how Flutter is architected to process large subtree changes and still maintain 60fps.

--------

Flutter friends from Chicago, let's welcome Andrew Brogdon from the Flutter team at Google! This is an incredible opportunity for our local community! I can't thank Andrew enough for making the effort to visit us and share his knowledge with us!

Happy coding! 👩‍💻👨‍💻

Thanks to the Flutter Chicago group for making this event possible check out their meetup page for future Flutter events (https://www.meetup.com/Flutter-Chicago)

events.name: Google Cloud Study Jam: Kubernetes
events.description:
Join a community of like-minded developers and explore the latest Google Cloud technologies as a team. Join us for our upcoming Cloud Study Jam and get hands-on experience with Kubernetes! More details to follow on course!

After the Study Jam, you’ll receive 30-days free access to the entire Qwiklabs catalog, so you can keep developing your skills at home! Complete all of the labs in the session’s quest, and you’ll earn an additional free month of access to Qwiklabs as well as a badge for your online profile.

Bring a laptop and charger (PC, Mac or Chromebook)! The labs will run on all of the latest versions of popular browsers. For the best experience, make sure your laptop has Firefox or Chrome installed. Don’t forget your charger.

events.name: Site Reliability Engineering At Google
events.description:
Site Reliability Engineering; what does is it mean? How does this differ from DevOps? How can I implement SRE practices in my day to day? Come learn and discuss how to implement SRE in your day to day from Jose Andrade from Google!

About Speaker:
Jose Andrade is a Cloud Consultant at Google with over 18 years of experience working in infrastructure, automation and software development. He currently helps large enterprise customers implement cloud technologies with a focus on reliability and scalability and helps local startups run their applications in GCP.

Before joining Google, Jose was a Senior Solutions Architect at Yale University, where he led a team of Senior DevOps Engineers in the development and implementation of custom solutions for consumption and automation of cloud services. He also worked for the federal Judicial
branch as a software engineer, and was a technology journalist with Engadget. He has organized DevOps conferences and community meet-ups with the goal of creating a more inclusive and diverse culture.

Jose holds a Master's degree in Information Management Systems from Harvard University and a BS in Management Information Systems from Liberty University. In his spare time he enjoys traveling the world with his wife and daughter.

Twitter: @jandrade

events.name: TypeScript vs. ReasonML - When Sh*t Gets Real
events.description:
Agenda:
5:30 - 6:00 - Food, Socializing and Announcements
6:00 - 6:20 - Frontend Testing: Mapping Out the Territory Presented by Gil Tayar
6:25 - 6:45 - TypeScript vs. ReasonML - When Sh*t Gets Real by Peter Piekarczyk

About the Talks:
TypeScript vs. ReasonML - When Sh*t Gets Real
Abstract: Building apps in Typescript has been the talk of the town in the past years. MSFT poured millions into making sure we’ve had types for every popular package and the community has helped deliver the rest.

But no matter how many times I ask Chicago Tech or however many Stackoverflow questions I read over, I still struggle typing the most intricate things. React? Node? It’s all the same. Over the last couple of years, I’ve learned a lot about how I can improve this and get the right type, every. single. time.

Frontend Testing: Mapping Out the Territory
Abstract: "Frontend testing is impossible! I don’t have time for it! It makes my productivity tank! My manager won’t allow me to do it!
These are all excuses for not writing tests for your frontend code. In the interest of time, I will focus on the real reasons - I don’t know how, I’m afraid to start - and alleviate the fear by just writing tests and showing how easy it is..
I will give a recipe that you can follow to ease your fear of the unknown—writing tests. I will discuss the various kinds of testing and how they fit together in a coherent way, but most importantly - I will give sample code that you can use as a template in your own project."

About the speakers

About Peter Piekarczyk:
Peter Piekarczyk is the co-founder & CTO of Draftbit, a platform that helps teams build React Native and Expo app visually. He’s been an entrepreneur his whole life but still has trouble spelling the word. Peter’s built and maintained projects for React, React Native, React Navigation, Apollo GraphQL and ReasonML.

About Gil Tayar:
From the olden days of DOS, to the contemporary world of Software Testing, Gil was, is, and always will be, a software developer. He has in the past co-founded WebCollage, survived the bubble collapse of 2000, and worked on various big cloudy projects at Wix.
His current passion is figuring out how to test software, a passion which he has turned into his main job as Evangelist and Senior Architect at Applitools. He has religiously tested all his software, from the early days as a junior software developer to the current days at Applitools, where he develops tests for software that tests software, which is almost one meta layer too many for him.

events.name: Data Studio Community Connectors and Visualization Code Lab
events.description:
Agenda:
6:00-6:30: Socialize Food and announcements
6:30-7:45: Codelab/Workshop
Bio:
Yulan is a Developer Advocate for Google’s Data Studio. She first learned to code through SQL GROUP BY statements and RNA-sequencing, and has since traded beakers and pipets for ridiculously complex dotfiles and data visualization. Prior to Google, she’s worked in research, event management, and government data science. When not computerating, she can be found reading, hosting dinner parties, and playing piano. You can find her on Twitter at y3l2n.

Abstract:
Data Studio is Google’s serverless business intelligence and data visualization platform. Community Visualizations provide a way to write custom data visualizations for Data Studio, and Community connectors allow you to connect data from different APIs to Data Studio Dashboards. This workshop will be an opportunity to work through the self-paced codelabs for Community Visualizations and Community Connectors with a Data Studio Developer Advocate nearby to provide an opinionated introduction, answer questions, and give additional context.

Pre-work/setup instructions ( https://docs.google.com/document/d/1rw0lEYV2qOipYk5QawoWUVo7w0HjTtZYL7TqXmBpTKs/edit?usp=sharing )
